trans-unit.source: Agile software development with Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Agile software development with Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create high-scale complex applications with Azure App Service in a way that supports agile software development.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create high-scale complex applications with Azure App Service in a way that supports agile software development.

trans-unit.source: Agile software development with Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Agile software development with Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create high-scale complex applications with [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) in a way that supports [agile software development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agile_software_development).
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create high-scale complex applications with [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) in a way that supports [agile software development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agile_software_development).

trans-unit.source: It assumes that you already know how to [deploy complex applications predictably in Azure](app-service-deploy-complex-application-predictably.md).
trans-unit.target: It assumes that you already know how to [deploy complex applications predictably in Azure](app-service-deploy-complex-application-predictably.md).

trans-unit.source: Limitations in technical processes can often stand in the way of successful implementation of agile methodologies.
trans-unit.target: Limitations in technical processes can often stand in the way of successful implementation of agile methodologies.

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service with features such as [continuous publishing](web-sites-publish-source-control.md), [staging environments](web-sites-staged-publishing.md) (slots), and [monitoring](web-sites-monitor.md), when coupled wisely with the orchestration and management of deployment in [Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-overview.md), can be part of a great solution for developers who embrace agile software development.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service with features such as [continuous publishing](web-sites-publish-source-control.md), [staging environments](web-sites-staged-publishing.md) (slots), and [monitoring](web-sites-monitor.md), when coupled wisely with the orchestration and management of deployment in [Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-overview.md), can be part of a great solution for developers who embrace agile software development.

trans-unit.source: The following table is a short list of requirements associated with agile development, and how Azure services enables each of them.
trans-unit.target: The following table is a short list of requirements associated with agile development, and how Azure services enables each of them.

trans-unit.source: Requirement
trans-unit.target: Requirement

trans-unit.source: How Azure enables
trans-unit.target: How Azure enables

trans-unit.source: - Build with every commit
trans-unit.target: - Build with every commit

trans-unit.source: - Build automatically and fast
trans-unit.target: - Build automatically and fast

trans-unit.source: When configured with continuous deployment, Azure App Service can function as live-running builds based on a dev branch.
trans-unit.target: When configured with continuous deployment, Azure App Service can function as live-running builds based on a dev branch.

trans-unit.source: Every time code is pushed to the branch, it is automatically built and running live in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Every time code is pushed to the branch, it is automatically built and running live in Azure.

trans-unit.source: - Make builds self-testing
trans-unit.target: - Make builds self-testing

trans-unit.source: Load tests, web tests, etc., can be deployed with the Azure Resource Manager template.
trans-unit.target: Load tests, web tests, etc., can be deployed with the Azure Resource Manager template.

trans-unit.source: - Perform tests in a clone of production environment
trans-unit.target: - Perform tests in a clone of production environment

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager templates can be used to create clones of the Azure production environment (including app settings, connection string templates, scaling, etc.) for testing quickly and predictably.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager templates can be used to create clones of the Azure production environment (including app settings, connection string templates, scaling, etc.) for testing quickly and predictably.

trans-unit.source: - View result of latest build easily
trans-unit.target: - View result of latest build easily

trans-unit.source: Continuous deployment to Azure from a repository means that you can test new code in a live application immediately after you commit your changes.
trans-unit.target: Continuous deployment to Azure from a repository means that you can test new code in a live application immediately after you commit your changes.

trans-unit.source: - Commit to the main branch every day
trans-unit.target: - Commit to the main branch every day

trans-unit.source: - Automate deployment
trans-unit.target: - Automate deployment

trans-unit.source: Continuous integration of a production application with a repository’s main branch automatically deploys every commit/merge to the main branch to production.
trans-unit.target: Continuous integration of a production application with a repository’s main branch automatically deploys every commit/merge to the main branch to production.

trans-unit.source: What you will do
trans-unit.target: What you will do

trans-unit.source: You will walk through a typical dev-test-stage-production workflow in order to publish new changes to the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) sample application, which consists of two [web apps](/services/app-service/web/), one being a frontend (FE) and the other being a Web API backend (BE), and a [SQL database](/services/sql-database/).
trans-unit.target: You will walk through a typical dev-test-stage-production workflow in order to publish new changes to the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) sample application, which consists of two [web apps](/services/app-service/web/), one being a frontend (FE) and the other being a Web API backend (BE), and a [SQL database](/services/sql-database/).

trans-unit.source: You will work with the deployment architecture shown below:
trans-unit.target: You will work with the deployment architecture shown below:

trans-unit.source: To put the picture into words :
trans-unit.target: To put the picture into words :

trans-unit.source: The deployment architecture is separated into three distinct environments (or [resource groups](resource-group-overview.md) in Azure), each with its own [App Service plan](azure-web-sites-web-hosting-plans-in-depth-overview.md), [scaling](web-sites-scale.md) settings, and SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The deployment architecture is separated into three distinct environments (or [resource groups](resource-group-overview.md) in Azure), each with its own [App Service plan](azure-web-sites-web-hosting-plans-in-depth-overview.md), [scaling](web-sites-scale.md) settings, and SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Each environment can be managed separately.
trans-unit.target: Each environment can be managed separately.

trans-unit.source: They can even exist in different subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: They can even exist in different subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Staging and production are implemented as two slots of the same App Service app.
trans-unit.target: Staging and production are implemented as two slots of the same App Service app.

trans-unit.source: The master branch is setup for continuous integration with the staging slot.
trans-unit.target: The master branch is setup for continuous integration with the staging slot.

trans-unit.source: When a commit to master branch is verified on the staging slot (with production data), the verified staging app is swapped into the production slot [with no downtime](web-sites-staged-publishing.md).
trans-unit.target: When a commit to master branch is verified on the staging slot (with production data), the verified staging app is swapped into the production slot [with no downtime](web-sites-staged-publishing.md).

trans-unit.source: The production and staging environment is defined by the template at [*<repository_root>*/ARMTemplates/ProdandStage.json](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp/blob/master/ARMTemplates/ProdAndStage.json).
trans-unit.target: The production and staging environment is defined by the template at [*<repository_root>*/ARMTemplates/ProdandStage.json](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp/blob/master/ARMTemplates/ProdAndStage.json).

trans-unit.source: The dev and test environments are defined by the template at [*<repository_root>*/ARMTemplates/Dev.json](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp/blob/master/ARMTemplates/Dev.json).
trans-unit.target: The dev and test environments are defined by the template at [*<repository_root>*/ARMTemplates/Dev.json](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp/blob/master/ARMTemplates/Dev.json).

trans-unit.source: You will also use the typical branching strategy, with code moving from the dev branch up to the test branch, then to the master branch (moving up in quality, so to speak).
trans-unit.target: You will also use the typical branching strategy, with code moving from the dev branch up to the test branch, then to the master branch (moving up in quality, so to speak).

trans-unit.source: What you will need
trans-unit.target: What you will need

trans-unit.source: An Azure account
trans-unit.target: An Azure account

trans-unit.source: A [GitHub](https://github.com/) account
trans-unit.target: A [GitHub](https://github.com/) account

trans-unit.source: Git Shell (installed with [GitHub for Windows](https://windows.github.com/)) - this enables you to run both the Git and PowerShell commands in the same session
trans-unit.target: Git Shell (installed with [GitHub for Windows](https://windows.github.com/)) - this enables you to run both the Git and PowerShell commands in the same session

trans-unit.source: Latest [Azure PowerShell](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases/download/0.9.4-June2015/azure-powershell.0.9.4.msi) bits
trans-unit.target: Latest [Azure PowerShell](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases/download/0.9.4-June2015/azure-powershell.0.9.4.msi) bits

trans-unit.source: Basic understanding of the following:
trans-unit.target: Basic understanding of the following:

trans-unit.source: [Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-overview.md) template deployment (also see [Deploy a complex application predictably in Azure](app-service-deploy-complex-application-predictably.md))
trans-unit.target: [Azure Resource Manager](resource-group-overview.md) template deployment (also see [Deploy a complex application predictably in Azure](app-service-deploy-complex-application-predictably.md))

trans-unit.source: Git
trans-unit.target: Git

trans-unit.source: PowerShell
trans-unit.target: PowerShell

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Azure account to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: You can [open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F) - You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: You can [open an Azure account for free](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F) - You get credits you can use to try out paid Azure services, and even after they're used up you can keep the account and use free Azure services, such as Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: You can [activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F) - Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.
trans-unit.target: You can [activate MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F) - Your MSDN subscription gives you credits every month that you can use for paid Azure services.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Set up your production environment
trans-unit.target: Set up your production environment

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The script used in this tutorial will automatically configure continuous publishing from your GitHub repository.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The script used in this tutorial will automatically configure continuous publishing from your GitHub repository.

trans-unit.source: This requires that your GitHub credentials are already stored in Azure, otherwise the scripted deployment will fail when attempting to configure source control settings for the web apps.
trans-unit.target: This requires that your GitHub credentials are already stored in Azure, otherwise the scripted deployment will fail when attempting to configure source control settings for the web apps.

trans-unit.source: To store your GitHub credentials in Azure, create a web app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and [configure GitHub deployment](web-sites-publish-source-control.md#Step7).
trans-unit.target: To store your GitHub credentials in Azure, create a web app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and [configure GitHub deployment](web-sites-publish-source-control.md#Step7).

trans-unit.source: You only need to do this once.
trans-unit.target: You only need to do this once.

trans-unit.source: In a typical DevOps scenario, you have an application that’s running live in Azure, and you want to make changes to it through continuous publishing.
trans-unit.target: In a typical DevOps scenario, you have an application that’s running live in Azure, and you want to make changes to it through continuous publishing.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you have a template that you developed, tested, and used to deploy the production environment.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you have a template that you developed, tested, and used to deploy the production environment.

trans-unit.source: You will set it up in this section.
trans-unit.target: You will set it up in this section.

trans-unit.source: Create your own fork of the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) repository.
trans-unit.target: Create your own fork of the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) repository.

trans-unit.source: For information on creating your fork, see [Fork a Repo](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/).
trans-unit.target: For information on creating your fork, see [Fork a Repo](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/).

trans-unit.source: Once your fork is created, you can see it in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Once your fork is created, you can see it in your browser.

trans-unit.source: Open a Git Shell session.
trans-unit.target: Open a Git Shell session.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have Git Shell yet, install [GitHub for Windows](https://windows.github.com/) now.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have Git Shell yet, install [GitHub for Windows](https://windows.github.com/) now.

trans-unit.source: Create a local clone of your fork by executing the following command:
trans-unit.target: Create a local clone of your fork by executing the following command:

trans-unit.source: Once you have your local clone, navigate to *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates, and run the deploy.ps1 script as follows:
trans-unit.target: Once you have your local clone, navigate to *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates, and run the deploy.ps1 script as follows:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.

trans-unit.source: You should see the provisioning progress of various Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: You should see the provisioning progress of various Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: When deployment completes, the script will launch the application in the browser and give you a friendly beep.
trans-unit.target: When deployment completes, the script will launch the application in the browser and give you a friendly beep.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Take a look at *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates\Deploy.ps1, to see how it generates resources with unique IDs.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Take a look at *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates\Deploy.ps1, to see how it generates resources with unique IDs.

trans-unit.source: You can use the same approach to create clones of the same deployment without worrying about conflicting resource names.
trans-unit.target: You can use the same approach to create clones of the same deployment without worrying about conflicting resource names.

trans-unit.source: Back in your Git Shell session, run:
trans-unit.target: Back in your Git Shell session, run:

trans-unit.source: When the script finishes, go back to browse to the frontend’s address (http://ToDoApp*<unique_string>*master.azurewebsites.net/) to see the application running in production.
trans-unit.target: When the script finishes, go back to browse to the frontend’s address (http://ToDoApp*<unique_string>*master.azurewebsites.net/) to see the application running in production.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and take a look at what’s created.
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and take a look at what’s created.

trans-unit.source: You should be able to see two web apps in the same resource group, one with the `Api` suffix in the name.
trans-unit.target: You should be able to see two web apps in the same resource group, one with the `Api` suffix in the name.

trans-unit.source: If you look at the resource group view, you will also see the SQL Database and server, the App Service plan, and the staging slots for the web apps.
trans-unit.target: If you look at the resource group view, you will also see the SQL Database and server, the App Service plan, and the staging slots for the web apps.

trans-unit.source: Browse through the different resources and compare them with *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates\ProdAndStage.json to see how they are configured in the template.
trans-unit.target: Browse through the different resources and compare them with *<repository_root>*\ARMTemplates\ProdAndStage.json to see how they are configured in the template.

trans-unit.source: You have now set up the production environment.
trans-unit.target: You have now set up the production environment.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will kick off a new update to the application.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will kick off a new update to the application.

trans-unit.source: Create dev and test branches
trans-unit.target: Create dev and test branches

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a complex application running in production in Azure, you will make an update to your application in accordance with agile methodology.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a complex application running in production in Azure, you will make an update to your application in accordance with agile methodology.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create the dev and test branches that you will need to make the required updates.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create the dev and test branches that you will need to make the required updates.

trans-unit.source: Create the test environment first.
trans-unit.target: Create the test environment first.

trans-unit.source: In your Git Shell session, run the following commands to create the environment for a new branch called **NewUpdate**.
trans-unit.target: In your Git Shell session, run the following commands to create the environment for a new branch called **NewUpdate**.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.

trans-unit.source: When deployment completes, the script will launch the application in the browser and give you a friendly beep.
trans-unit.target: When deployment completes, the script will launch the application in the browser and give you a friendly beep.

trans-unit.source: And just like that, you now have a new branch with its own test environment.
trans-unit.target: And just like that, you now have a new branch with its own test environment.

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to review a few things about this test environment:
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to review a few things about this test environment:

trans-unit.source: You can create it in any Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can create it in any Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: That means the production environment can be managed separately from your test environment.
trans-unit.target: That means the production environment can be managed separately from your test environment.

trans-unit.source: Your test environment is running live in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Your test environment is running live in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Your test environment is identical to the production environment, except for the staging slots and the scaling settings.
trans-unit.target: Your test environment is identical to the production environment, except for the staging slots and the scaling settings.

trans-unit.source: You can know this because these are the only differences between ProdandStage.json and Dev.json.
trans-unit.target: You can know this because these are the only differences between ProdandStage.json and Dev.json.

trans-unit.source: You can manage your test environment in its own App Service plan, with a different price tier (such as **Free**).
trans-unit.target: You can manage your test environment in its own App Service plan, with a different price tier (such as **Free**).

trans-unit.source: Deleting this test environment will be as simple as deleting the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Deleting this test environment will be as simple as deleting the resource group.

trans-unit.source: You will find out how to do this [later](#delete).
trans-unit.target: You will find out how to do this [later](#delete).

trans-unit.source: Go on to create a dev branch by running the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Go on to create a dev branch by running the following commands:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, type in the desired username and password for database access.

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to review a few things about this dev environment:
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to review a few things about this dev environment:

trans-unit.source: Your dev environment has a configuration identical to the test environment because it’s deployed using the same template.
trans-unit.target: Your dev environment has a configuration identical to the test environment because it’s deployed using the same template.

trans-unit.source: Each dev environment can be created in the developer’s own Azure subscription, leaving the test environment to be separately managed.
trans-unit.target: Each dev environment can be created in the developer’s own Azure subscription, leaving the test environment to be separately managed.

trans-unit.source: Your dev environment is running live in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Your dev environment is running live in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Deleting the dev environment is as simple as deleting the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Deleting the dev environment is as simple as deleting the resource group.

trans-unit.source: You will find out how to do this [later](#delete).
trans-unit.target: You will find out how to do this [later](#delete).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When you have multiple developers working on the new update, each of them can easily create a branch and dedicated dev environment by doing the following:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When you have multiple developers working on the new update, each of them can easily create a branch and dedicated dev environment by doing the following:

trans-unit.source: Create their own fork of the repository in GitHub (see [Fork a Repo](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/)).
trans-unit.target: Create their own fork of the repository in GitHub (see [Fork a Repo](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/)).

trans-unit.source: Clone the fork on their local machine
trans-unit.target: Clone the fork on their local machine

trans-unit.source: Run the same commands to create their own dev branch and environment.
trans-unit.target: Run the same commands to create their own dev branch and environment.

trans-unit.source: When you’re done, your GitHub fork should have three branches:
trans-unit.target: When you’re done, your GitHub fork should have three branches:

trans-unit.source: And you should have six web apps (three sets of two) in three separate resource groups:
trans-unit.target: And you should have six web apps (three sets of two) in three separate resource groups:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Note that ProdandStage.json specifies the production environment to use the **Standard** pricing tier, which is appropriate for scalability of the production application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Note that ProdandStage.json specifies the production environment to use the **Standard** pricing tier, which is appropriate for scalability of the production application.

trans-unit.source: Build and test every commit
trans-unit.target: Build and test every commit

trans-unit.source: The template files ProdAndStage.json and Dev.json already specify the source control parameters, which by default sets up continuous publishing for the web app.
trans-unit.target: The template files ProdAndStage.json and Dev.json already specify the source control parameters, which by default sets up continuous publishing for the web app.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, every commit to the GitHub branch triggers an automatic deployment to Azure from that branch.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, every commit to the GitHub branch triggers an automatic deployment to Azure from that branch.

trans-unit.source: Let’s see how your setup works now.
trans-unit.target: Let’s see how your setup works now.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you’re in the Dev branch of the local repository.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you’re in the Dev branch of the local repository.

trans-unit.source: To do this, run the following command in Git Shell:
trans-unit.target: To do this, run the following command in Git Shell:

trans-unit.source: Make a simple change to the app’s UI layer by changing the code to use [Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/components/) lists.
trans-unit.target: Make a simple change to the app’s UI layer by changing the code to use [Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/components/) lists.

trans-unit.source: Open *<repository_root>*\src\MultiChannelToDo.Web\app\index.cshtml and make the highlighted change below:
trans-unit.target: Open *<repository_root>*\src\MultiChannelToDo.Web\app\index.cshtml and make the highlighted change below:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you can't read the image above:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you can't read the image above:

trans-unit.source: In line 18, change `check-list` to `list-group`.
trans-unit.target: In line 18, change `check-list` to `list-group`.

trans-unit.source: In line 19, change `class="check-list-item"` to `class="list-group-item"`.
trans-unit.target: In line 19, change `class="check-list-item"` to `class="list-group-item"`.

trans-unit.source: Save the change.
trans-unit.target: Save the change.

trans-unit.source: Back in Git Shell, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Back in Git Shell, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: These git commands are similar to "checking in your code" in another source control system like TFS.
trans-unit.target: These git commands are similar to "checking in your code" in another source control system like TFS.

trans-unit.source: When you run `git push`, the new commit triggers an automatic code push to Azure, which then rebuilds the application to reflect the change in the dev environment.
trans-unit.target: When you run `git push`, the new commit triggers an automatic code push to Azure, which then rebuilds the application to reflect the change in the dev environment.

trans-unit.source: To verify that this code push to your dev environment has occurred, go to your dev environment’s web app blade and look at the **Deployment** part.
trans-unit.target: To verify that this code push to your dev environment has occurred, go to your dev environment’s web app blade and look at the **Deployment** part.

trans-unit.source: You should be able to see your latest commit message there.
trans-unit.target: You should be able to see your latest commit message there.

trans-unit.source: From there, click **Browse** to see the new change in the live application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: From there, click **Browse** to see the new change in the live application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This is a pretty minor change to the application.
trans-unit.target: This is a pretty minor change to the application.

trans-unit.source: However, many times new changes to a complex web application has unintended and undesirable side effects.
trans-unit.target: However, many times new changes to a complex web application has unintended and undesirable side effects.

trans-unit.source: Being able to easily test every commit in live builds enables you to catch these issues before your customers see them.
trans-unit.target: Being able to easily test every commit in live builds enables you to catch these issues before your customers see them.

trans-unit.source: By now, you should be comfortable with the realization that, as a developer on the **NewUpdate** project, you will be able to easily create a dev environment for yourself, then build every commit and test every build.
trans-unit.target: By now, you should be comfortable with the realization that, as a developer on the **NewUpdate** project, you will be able to easily create a dev environment for yourself, then build every commit and test every build.

trans-unit.source: Merge code into test environment
trans-unit.target: Merge code into test environment

trans-unit.source: When you’re ready to push your code from Dev branch up to NewUpdate branch, it’s the standard git process:
trans-unit.target: When you’re ready to push your code from Dev branch up to NewUpdate branch, it’s the standard git process:

trans-unit.source: Merge any new commits to NewUpdate into the Dev branch in GitHub, such as commits created by other developers.
trans-unit.target: Merge any new commits to NewUpdate into the Dev branch in GitHub, such as commits created by other developers.

trans-unit.source: Any new commit on GitHub will trigger a code push and build in the dev environment.
trans-unit.target: Any new commit on GitHub will trigger a code push and build in the dev environment.

trans-unit.source: You can then make sure your code in Dev branch still works with the latest bits from NewUpdate branch.
trans-unit.target: You can then make sure your code in Dev branch still works with the latest bits from NewUpdate branch.

trans-unit.source: Merge all your new commits from Dev branch into NewUpdate branch on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Merge all your new commits from Dev branch into NewUpdate branch on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: This action triggers a code push and build in the test environment.
trans-unit.target: This action triggers a code push and build in the test environment.

trans-unit.source: Note again that because continuous deployment is already setup with these git branches, you don’t need to take any other action like running integration builds.
trans-unit.target: Note again that because continuous deployment is already setup with these git branches, you don’t need to take any other action like running integration builds.

trans-unit.source: You simply need to perform standard source control practices using git, and Azure will perform all the build processes for you.
trans-unit.target: You simply need to perform standard source control practices using git, and Azure will perform all the build processes for you.

trans-unit.source: Now, let’s push your code to **NewUpdate** branch.
trans-unit.target: Now, let’s push your code to **NewUpdate** branch.

trans-unit.source: In Git Shell, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In Git Shell, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: That’s it!
trans-unit.target: That’s it!

trans-unit.source: Go to the web app blade for your test environment to see your new commit (merged into NewUpdate branch) now pushed to the test environment.
trans-unit.target: Go to the web app blade for your test environment to see your new commit (merged into NewUpdate branch) now pushed to the test environment.

trans-unit.source: Then, click **Browse** to see that the style change is now running live in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Then, click **Browse** to see that the style change is now running live in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Deploy update to production
trans-unit.target: Deploy update to production

trans-unit.source: Pushing code to the staging and production environment should feel no different than what you’ve already done when you pushed code to the test environment.
trans-unit.target: Pushing code to the staging and production environment should feel no different than what you’ve already done when you pushed code to the test environment.

trans-unit.source: It's really that simple.
trans-unit.target: It's really that simple.

trans-unit.source: In Git Shell, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In Git Shell, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: Remember that based on the way the staging and production environment is setup in ProdandStage.json, your new code is pushed to the **Staging** slot and is running there.
trans-unit.target: Remember that based on the way the staging and production environment is setup in ProdandStage.json, your new code is pushed to the **Staging** slot and is running there.

trans-unit.source: So if you navigate to the staging slot’s URL, you’ll see the new code running there.
trans-unit.target: So if you navigate to the staging slot’s URL, you’ll see the new code running there.

trans-unit.source: To do this, run the `Show-AzureWebsite` cmdlet in Git Shell.
trans-unit.target: To do this, run the `Show-AzureWebsite` cmdlet in Git Shell.

trans-unit.source: And now, after you’ve verified the update in the staging slot, the only thing left to do is to swap it into production.
trans-unit.target: And now, after you’ve verified the update in the staging slot, the only thing left to do is to swap it into production.

trans-unit.source: In Git Shell, just run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In Git Shell, just run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You’ve successfully published a new update to your production web application.
trans-unit.target: You’ve successfully published a new update to your production web application.

trans-unit.source: What’s more is that you’ve just done it by easily creating dev and test environments, and building and testing every commit.
trans-unit.target: What’s more is that you’ve just done it by easily creating dev and test environments, and building and testing every commit.

trans-unit.source: These are crucial building blocks for agile software development.
trans-unit.target: These are crucial building blocks for agile software development.

trans-unit.source: Delete dev and test enviroments
trans-unit.target: Delete dev and test enviroments

trans-unit.source: Because you have purposely architected your dev and test environments to be self-contained resource groups, it is very easy to delete them.
trans-unit.target: Because you have purposely architected your dev and test environments to be self-contained resource groups, it is very easy to delete them.

trans-unit.source: To delete the ones you created in this tutorial, both the GitHub branches and Azure artifacts, just run the following commands in Git Shell:
trans-unit.target: To delete the ones you created in this tutorial, both the GitHub branches and Azure artifacts, just run the following commands in Git Shell:

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Agile software development is a must-have for many companies who want to adopt Azure as their application platform.
trans-unit.target: Agile software development is a must-have for many companies who want to adopt Azure as their application platform.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you have learned how to create and tear down exact replicas or near replicas of the production environment with ease, even for complex applications.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you have learned how to create and tear down exact replicas or near replicas of the production environment with ease, even for complex applications.

trans-unit.source: You have also learned how to leverage this ability to create a development process that can build and test every single commit in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You have also learned how to leverage this ability to create a development process that can build and test every single commit in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial has hopefully shown you how you can best use Azure App Service and Azure Resource Manager together to create a DevOps solution that caters to agile methodologies.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial has hopefully shown you how you can best use Azure App Service and Azure Resource Manager together to create a DevOps solution that caters to agile methodologies.
